[Bridge]
 I want her everywhere and if she’s beside me
 I know I need never care
 But to love her is to need her everywhere

A trained musical ear may notice that this bridge begins with a deceptive cadence: essentially, the dominant chord does not resolve to the tonic chord (in this case, D7), causing the bridge to bring an unexpected musical shift instead of the resolution that a listener expects.

McCartney’s use of this chord progression actually aligns perfectly with the lyrics of the song. Observe that both the Intro and Verse 1 use the word “here,” while Verse 2 and Verse 3 both end on “there.” Finally, on the bridge, McCartney finally sings that he wants and needs her “everywhere.”

Typically, a tonic chord (the D7) usually functions to bring the song back to its home key, but with the aforementioned chord progression, the bridge instead actually expands into a completely new direction.

In that lies a subtle part of the song’s genius: both the song’s lyrics and its chord progression literally go from “here,” to “there” and then to “everywhere.”

I will be there and everywhere
 Here, there and everywhere

Paul McCartney’s favourite among his own compositions, it is regarded as one of his finest love songs. It was written in Weybridge, alongside John Lennon’s swimming pool, while he waited for Lennon to wake up.

I sat out by the pool on one of the sun chairs with my guitar and started strumming in E, and soon had a few chords, and I think by the time he’d woken up, I had pretty much written the song, so we took it indoors and finished it up.
-Paul McCartney

While the song was written about Jane Asher, the vocal inspiration came from another beautiful lady who wasn’t dating Sir Paul.

When I sang it in the studio I remember thinking, I’ll sing it like Marianne Faithfull; something no one would ever know… So that was a little voice, I used an almost falsetto voice and double-tracked it. My Marianne Faithfull impression.
-Paul McCartney
Here, making each day of the year

Playing off of the common saying ‘making my day,’ the narrator says that if his love is by his side every day of the year, she helps ‘makes his day’ every day of the year; he’ll be happy all the time with her by his side.
To lead a better life I need my love to be here

We’re led to believe that ‘here’ is a place in the intro, but in the verses we see that the ‘here’ the narrator is talking about is wherever he is, whether it be ‘here’, ‘there’ or anywhere else in the world.

The narrator is claiming that no matter where he is in the world he knows he’ll live a good life if his love is by his side.
